If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider this as a repeated game with multiple rounds. In such a case, it is common to use strategies that maximize the average payoff over the long run.

In this game, if we always pick R (denoted as {R}), our expected payoff per round against an opponent who randomly picks either R or B would be [(45 * P(Opponent picks R)) + (0 * P(Opponent picks B))] / 2 = (45 * p) / 2, where p is the probability of the opponent picking R.

On the other hand, if we always pick B ({B}), our expected payoff per round would be [(40 * P(Opponent picks R)) + (20 * P(Opponent picks B))] / 2 = (10 * p + 20 * (1-p)) / 2.

Now, let's compare the two payoffs:

(45 * p) / 2 > (10 * p + 20 * (1-p)) / 2 if and only if (45 - 10) * p > (20 - 20 * p) if and only if 35p > 20(1-p).

To maximize our payoff, we want to satisfy the above inequality for all values of p. If we graph the functions y = 35p and y = 20(1-p), we can see that the inequality is satisfied when p > 2/7 (approximately 0.286).

So, if we believe our opponent picks R more than 28.6% of the time, it would be rational for us to always pick R ({R}). However, since this is an anonymous player and there's no information about their strategy, it might be wiser to mix strategies (randomly picking R or B) in order to exploit potential patterns in the opponent's choices. But if we had to make a decision based on the payoffs alone, {R} would be our choice as the best option for maximizing our average payoff over 75 rounds.
